Definition: Given a sentence, your responsibility is to classify it into two different classes, which are insult and non-insult. Classify as an insult if the sentence expresses any language that is rude or abusive.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Comment: The church presents celibacy as a charism, a gift, given to certain members of the believing community as a witness oriented to the kingdom of God in which women and men will neither marry nor be given in marriage. 
The Sacrament of Orders celebrates and confirms the call of certain members of the community to celebrate the sacraments of the church with and for their sisters and brothers.
There is no logical or necessary connection between the two.  A person gifted with the charism of celibacy may or may not be called to Orders; a person called to Orders may or may not also be entrusted with the charism of celibacy.
The discipline that links the two -- that requires celibacy as a condition for orders -- artificially shrinks the pool of candidates for orders, and it disfigures the charism of celibacy. "Mandatory celibacy" is an oxymoron, if celibacy is understood as a charism.
Enforcing celibacy on a widowed deacon is simply, incredibly stupid. The bishop ought to be ashamed.

I can see the argument for buying genuine indigenous art rather than fakes. Comment: The lower dam was apparently plugged by rafting up logs then submerging them by piling rock on them, to form a latticework plug, of sorts, so why not just dredge them out and let the river flow under the dam, then install a gate to store water for times of drought? The upper dam could have been similarly drilled under to allowed the lakes to refill in flood season, protecting downstream property and then used as a reservoir in Summer. We spent millions of scarce tax dollars for the aesthetics of a "wild" canyon for a few tourists. Once the lakes were drained the dams could collapse in an earthquake with no real harm done, but would likely stand if a seismic sensor automatically opened the drains if things started rocking. Now we have to spend millions more each year repairing flood damage and building new reservoirs, which will likely have their own hazards, and the animals and birds that had come to rely on those lakes for habitat had to move on or die. Idiots R Us. Your tax $ @ jerk.

Comment: No, I am really not. Philosophy - from the Greek "philos' meaning love and "sophos" meaning "Wisdom", the love of wisdom - is literally the study of how to think straight.

If you haven't learned philosophy, you will never be able to form a logical thought. No, what people think they are doing isn't logic. Logic is a set of rules. To think logically you have to know those rules, and apply those rules (much like algebra is a set of rules you have to know and apply to get the right answer).

To think you can be logical without studying philosophy is like claiming you can do algebra without learning to count first. 

Here's how it works:
Philosophers figure out how to understand things.
Scientists use those techniques to understand a particular thing.
Engineers use that understanding to solve practical problems.

Unfortunately - because true logic is so often counter-intuitive, those not schooled in it tend to think actual logical arguments are "stupid" because their intuition says so.

Comment: Not nearly as dumb as claiming the Deity's Name isn't "Allah", or foisting homosexual King James as some kind of "religious authority".  (Sigh) again--here's how it works:

Allah & Allahumma (Arabic) = Alah & Alaha (old Aramaic) = Elah & Elohim (Hebrew).

Those Semitic Names have likewise been translated as Olah (Zulu), Khuda (Farsi), Bogu (Russian), Dieu (French), Atu'a (Samoan), El Dio (Spanish), Hotheos (Greek), Astvats (Armenian), Bog (Hungarian), Xwede (Khurdish), Gott (German) and...GOD (English).

Arabic CHRISTIANS have ALWAYS invoked the Deity by the Name ALLAH.  So did the Messiah (alayhis-Salaam) when he (allegedly) cried out "Eli, Eli lama sabachthani!" from the cross.  The Greeks transliterated "Allah" as "Eli".

Glad I could help.  Anything else you wanna know about the Scriptures and/or their languages, just ask.  Or,  you can adopt the standard "evangelical logic" so succinctly described by Bill Watterson: "Why expend effort learning when ignorance is instantaneous?"

Comment: Stopping work on the Site C dam would be stupid.

Comment: Can't change the lower chamber without considering the upper chamber too. The two most be put together and work well  in order to move legislation smoothly. The reform/abolition of the Senate has been on the country's political plate for decades - unlike grand changes to House of Commons. One of the goals with these proposed changes to the House  is to move legislation along more smoothly. We can't make grand changes to one chamber, without thinking very hard about the other. To do it"one at a time" would be politically impossible and stupid. Has there been any call from the people whatsoever for a complete change to our system of government? Nope. I think Senate should be first thing looked at, with one referendum question "Change it or abolish it?" If "change" wins, then start all the negotiations to change it and "combine it with a new House. Don't start the House without thinking of the Senate.

Comment: I'm reminded of that landmark paper: _The Basic Laws of Human Stupidity_ by Carlo M. Cipolla, Former Professor of Economics at University UC Berkeley.

-First Law: Always and inevitably everyone underestimates the number of stupid individuals in circulation.
-Second Law: The probability that a certain person be stupid is independent of any other characteristic of that person.
-Third (and Golden) Law: A stupid person is a person who causes losses to another person or to a group of persons while himself deriving no gain and even possibly incurring losses.
-Fourth Law: Non-stupid people always underestimate the damaging power of stupid individuals. In particular non-stupid people constantly forget that at -all times and places and under any circumstances to deal and/or associate with stupid people always turns out to be a costly mistake.
-Fifth Law: A stupid person is the most dangerous type of person.
-Corollary to the 5th Law: A stupid person is more dangerous than a bandit.

Paul

Comment: Our LCBO is just a long standing remnant of prohibition.  Basically, alcohol sales are banned in the Province of Ontario.  A person or company cannot sell alcohol to another person, period.   

There are two exceptions, beer sales through a privately owned "brewer's co-operative" and sales by the province through the Liquor Control Board.  

So, if you want to sell alcohol in Ontario, what you do is sell your alcohol to the LCBO, at whatever price they determine it is worth (no competition, so you get what they give you) and the LCBO resells it at whatever markup they please (usually 200 to 300%).  

What we have now is a public service union that wants to get in on this cash bonanza with the usual full time, high salary "jobs for life".  The only grounds for all of this, is that the govt is "protecting us" from the evils of alcohol, by selling it to us at hugely inflated prices, and preventing anyone else from doing the same.  

That is it.  It's a morality play.  Stupidity.

Comment: Agree that Bannon's pushing to get out of the Paris Accord was a terrible move.

"Climate Change" is the closest thing there is to a world religion.  Even the DPRK has signed on to the Paris Accord, not of course, that it really affects them in any material way.

Giving notice to withdraw from the Paris Accord has been a complete disaster with respect to the allies we desperately need during this extremely perilous time.  The U.K., France, and Germany are good examples of this.

Trump should have simply smiled and pursued the tact that Xi & Modi have -- i.e.  tacit agreement but still acting in their nation's best interest.

Since Bannon helped to orchestrate Trump's upset win he's certainly not an "idiot" with respect to grass roots politics.  He might well be deemed an "idiot" for the disastrous effect his climate change stance has had on our geo-political security.

Comment: I disagree with the idea that "it’s easier to start out with more regulations than to try to regulate after the fact". It may be easier for the government; it is most certainly not easier for those being regulated. Repealing pointless regulations tends to be a low priority for government; repealing regulations that should not exist but are supported by a small constituency is even lower priority. The result is that if "more regulations" are put in place, they ossify and it often takes decades to get rid of them after it's clear that they are a mistake.

Marijuana prohibition itself is a horrible example. It was done by regulation without any debate or examination of the (lack of) scientific evidence to support prohibition; fifty years after the fact, the LeDain Commission recognized that prohibition was a mistake, and more than forty years after that we are finally moving to legalize. In other words, we had a bad regulation in 1923 and by the time we're rid of it, 95 years has passed.

Comment: When confronted by one of his blatant falsehoods, Trump often doesn’t even attempt to back up what he said. He’ll simply reply that “many people say I’m right,” effectively denying the validity of what is usually known as “facts.” The president is responding to a claim of fact not by denying the fact, but by denying the claim that facts are supposed to have on an argument. “He isn’t telling (his opponent) that he’s got his facts wrong. He’s saying that as far as he is concerned facts, as most people understand the term, don’t matter. That they are indistinguishable from, and interchangeable with, opinion, and that statements of fact needn’t have any purchase against a man who is either sufficiently powerful to ignore them or sufficiently shameless to deny them – or, in his case, both.”Bret Stephen’s editor and columnist at the Wall Street Journal

Comment: New cars do depreciate, but how much is largely dependent on the car. Some come very close to long-term deprecation rate. Luxury cars depreciate most, exotic cars with low mileage and some Toyotas depreciate least.

However, buying used isn't always the best choice. First, "nobody washes a rental car" and most people treat leases as rentals. Second, you will pay dealership markup, so above fair market value, to buy such car. This is even before "Certified Used" scams. Plus, with many people going for 8 year "mortgage" on cars, off the lease 2-3 year old cars are rare.  Third, you will not be eligible for manufacturer rebates when buying used.

As such, I believe the best value is to buy a new car that tends to hold value (e.g. Subaru, Toyota) at the year end when most manufacturers offer discounts to move last-year models off the lot. If there is a redesigned new incoming model you will get even bigger discount. Then you hold on to this car for 6-8 years and then privately sell it.

Comment: Thank you, Sister, for your timely post.  Seeing Jesus from both a human and divine seems to be so very difficult for us to do.  I have some Lenten seasons looked at Jesus through his human nature; at other time his divine.  Not often have I been able to wrap my mind around both at the the same time through this season.  However, as I was reading your meditation, it popped into my mind that just a short while ago, I know how not how long, I read about a mother who put her body over her child to protect the child from an attacker.  The child survived, but the mother died in this sacrificial act of saving her child.  This image in my mind, helped me to understand that yes, Jesus yielded fully to God's Will to bring us mercy, forgiveness, of sins at a great cost.  Not only what it cost God, but his humanity he yielded as well.  So much so, that its brutality is recorded in Biblical history.  Writing about events always diminishes its actual impact, as that differs by who is telling it.

Comment: I've been involved in sled dog sports for nineteen years. Comment: I wonder how many times the media have to repeat the fact that American airports, DIA included, generate their own revenue and are NOT funded by taxpayers?  No "DIA gate" has ever been put on the taxpayers' tab.

And LAX, ORD, and JFK, while generally band-aided beyond recognition, have very well-used gates and have no problems with attracting airlines.  Thankfully Denver's leaders in the 80's and 90's had the vision to build an airport that had room to expand at relatively low cost without ending up in the multiple-terminal goat rodeo of some major American airports.

Comment: Indeed, but I think there is an additional nuance.

Remember that when this dialogue was originally used, the people had elected the person they wanted to preside at their eucharist. That is, they had recognised in that person a natural but Spirit-given gift to lead them in shared prayer. Ordination was a prayer that this person be strengthened by the Spirit to put this [Spirit-given] gift at the service of the community.

So I believe "... with your spirit" was not just a recognition of ordination, but the people affirming why they chose this person to be ordained to be the presider at their Eucharist.

So I say, yes by all means ask the people to respond "And with your Spirit" ... but FIRST restore the ancient tradition of the people choosing their candidate for ordination. In that way their response would more genuinely be recognising an ecclesial reality.

Comment: So, Neko, I tend to agree with your assessment of the status quo. But what would happen if we all backed away from the table one step and rethought our assumptions? It might look something like this.
1. Stakeholder #1: the fetus will continue to term unless there is an intervention. Therefore, we may say that the fetus "prefers" to continue the pregnancy and will not/cannot take a different initiative that affects the ethical outcome. (A spontaneous abortion is not an initiative.)
2. Stakeholder #2: the woman is subject to conflicting forces, some of which incline her to carry the fetus to term and some of which incline her to terminate the pregnancy.  Since the actual decision is eventually hers, the question is whether the negative factors can (or should be) neutralized.
3. Stakeholder #3: family/society are also conflicted about the pregnancy, desiring to support both fetus and woman. The questions is whether family/society can resolve the conflicts. (More after dinner is cooked...)

Comment: I am one of the new teachers that Cathe is mentoring.  From my experience teaching this year and the year I spent working in rural Alaska years ago, I can say the reasons for the teacher retention are systemic to the whole set-up of village life, cultural conflicts, and the greater culture of the United States.  I don't believe throwing money at the issues will solve it.  I do believe that all first year teachers need a mentor, regardless of their location in the country. I also don't see that it matters on the employer of the mentor (if the mentor is competent).  Whether the mentor is through UAA, the district, the school, or another place, it matters more so that the mentor can help with the actual issues that the teacher is dealing with (whether that is inner city New York or Chefornak).  The mentor cannot just help with pedagogy.  Pedagogy is likely the least issue with which a first year teacher is dealing.

Comment: A touching and poignant description of the bittersweet effects of  dementia. Our family is going through this now, as my father, formerly a skilled and competent peadetrician has just been admitted into a home. This mixture of a new father is still deserving of love.

Comment: Warren Buffett said "Investing is simple, but not easy". Principles of asset allocation, risk and return are simple, but it's not easy to tune out the market gyrations, and financial industry news/noise. But yeah, there is enough investing information available free, and low-cost investing options like ETFs, eSeries funds and robo-advisers that many people should be able to do it on their own.

Financial planning (what the subjects paid for) is much harder. It requires understanding of rates of return, tax rates, tax-efficient investing, when to take CPP & OAS,  minimizing OAS clawback, tax-impact of a spouse passing away, how tax rates change as CPP & OAS start and mandatory RRIF withdrawls begin at age 72, and which accounts to draw from. It's hard to model those things without financial planning software that considers income and tax rates through the investor's working life and retirement. 

In my experience having a fee only plan done as retirement approaches is well worthwhile.

Comment: Key word in the story's headline: "could."  Nobody knows for sure, and I'm not talking about the factors of international trade.  YOU, the consumer, have the power to fool them.  Here's how. 
1. Cut back on eating out.  Personally, I disagree with lumping restaurant meals in with grocery shopping--in our household budget, dining out is "entertainment"--but okay, I'll go with the flow. Just do it less, and when you do, go to sandwich shops rather than big restaurants.  

2. Go grocery shopping more frequently and buy less when you do.  Sounds idiotic, but it's true. You can save big time.  Here's why, from a 2014 CBC story:
"More than $31 billion worth of food is wasted every year in Canada and when energy, water and other resource costs are factored in the true cost could be up to three times that much..."

And almost HALF that food wasteage is ... from households. You and me.  We buy more than we could possibly eat before it goes moldly, limp or mushy (Google Canadian food wasteage)

Comment: I am surprised and happy that David is writing about the importance of community building.  I started a farmers' market in rural Lane County, and it has been the most rewarding volunteer work in over 20 years of activism.  Not only does it help support local farmers and artists in our local community and food security,  it has been great for neighbors meeting neighbors; we have had community picnics, emergency preparedness and other events and efforts as a result of the farmers' market.   I believe local grassroots efforts are the path to resilience and good health.  Implementing decentralized energy and agriculture is key.  Bioregionalism is key.  Sourcing basic necessities close to home. Protecting our ecosystems and their basic services.  We are headed towards mass species extinction due to global warming, human population explosion, toxic chemicals, factory farming, etc. and it should be "all hands on deck" to mitigate and change this course. Keep it local, organic and sustainable.

One other comment...

The large build in speculative length in crude is associated with a large net short position among commercial traders [read:  producers].  This is consistent with the net sum zero makeup of futures markets, and makes sense as shale producers hedge prices to lock in margins on new drilling.  The thing is, for producers to perfect their hedge, all they need do is produce the necessary barrels.  That is, producers have no reason to close their net short position... Not true for speculators.

Comment: DOC's Mission statement, ".......Offenders in our charge will be treated in a safe and humane manner" .........is apparently something only for show.
In addition to the department's mission statement, the DOC must adhere to the Federal "Prison Rape Elimination Act of 2003" passed by the United States Congress. In DOC's P&P. chapter 800, Section 808.001, Prisoner Rights, 808.19, defines sexual acts, sexual abuse, sexual harassment and sexual misconduct, (this P&P ispoorly written/defined). 
There is AS 11.61.123. Indecent Viewing, but it's ambiguous when it comes to Corrections. 
Last, but not least is, UN's Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Articles 3&5, "...security of person..." and "No one shall be subjected to torture or to cruel, inhuman,or degrading treatment or punishment."
The "little" violations of humane treatment, sexual harassment, and human rights may cost the State of Alaska a "little" bit money.
Has the jailer become the offender and violated basic human rights?

Comment: Bikes don't pay taxes, and neither do cars.  People do.  

That might sound like a flippant response, but it gets to the core of your complaint in a subtle way: driving less and biking more helps with road maintenance funding.  The reason is a little complicated; I'm sorry not everything is perfectly simple, but the short version looks like this.

Everyone pays taxes.  Most road maintenance money in Oregon comes from the general fund, which most of us pay into through income and/or property taxes.  Some comes from auto registration and licensing; most who ride bicycles pay for that as well (fully car-free people are, even in Portland, a rarity).  Some comes from gas tax; that's paid by drivers of gas or diesel cars (but not electric cars), long-haul truckers, etc.  The amount that last generates is more than offset by the reduced road wear when a car owner rides a bicycle instead of driving.

There's a myth of "road tax" paying for the roads, but it's just that - myth.  Let it die.  :)

Comment: “No, progressives don;t want merely to develop doctrine, they want to change it ”

You can;t know what isn't true. So you can;t know that progessive Catholics think doctrinal development aims to reverse [Church] teaching.

Take the example of capital punishment. I don’t know anyone who would contest that the Church has taught that capital punishment is allowed in some cases. We also teach that Jesus was a victim of capital punishment. It is not hard to imagine that Jesus on the Cross might inspire the Church to repudiate the way he was killed, ie oppose capital punishment. This would change Church teaching on capital punishment because there is an implicit conflict that has not yet been resolved. Development would lead to abrogation of “settled” teaching. 
That has not happened yet, and may never, but I am pretty sure Newman allowed for that type of change.

Comment: The Miata or MX-5 is my preference for several reasons.
What do you want from a sportscar/convertible?  Open roof driving simplicity, reliability, and safety.  The Miata has these in spades, & at a much more reasonable price.
The body on the Miata is built like a tank or armoured car.  Our second Miata was sideswiped by a mid size car, and suffered only superficial damages, the front end of the other car required major structural and body work.
The electric sun roof, is also a great addition.   Spacious, reasonably quiet, and easy to operate, without loss of trunk nor cabin space.  Look for later model Miata's for this feature.
We drove a Z-4, and found it to be a guy's car, too long in the front and too manly in appearance.  Yes it does have a slight edge in performance, but at several costs, besides, what is the purpose of this car to be?  If it's a replacement (sic) for your father's MGB, the Miata is the modern day MGB.

Comment: I'm wondering why the City is only applying for a license to use the Camisa water now. And this flurry of activity is too little too late. Everything seems to be in assessment or first phase when this could  have been done years ago.

Non-potable water can have a lot of uses, eg. construction, which uses an enormous amount of water. Building sites should not use tap water. Because builders don't pay for water, they waste a lot. 

Office blocks and large residential blocks can have their own mini treatment plants to recycle water for reuse for gardens, toilets and pools. People with pools could also use rain water to replenish, storage enforced at the planning stage. 

The cost of water purification is a large part of any costing - why not pass it on to households? The technology exists. 

Water education is prime. I'm not aware of anything that isn't ad hoc.

We need to be a lot smarter and think out of the box. Get in experts from water scarce countries like Israel if you get stuck.

Comment: The only new per-page fee in the bill is the 10 cent per page default scanning charge (compared to 15 cents for paper photocopies). What we determined was that it's actually fairly rare for people to need scans of documents that are in good shape to drop in an automatic scanner, since such documents are almost always already available in native electronic form (Microsoft Word, for example). The records most commonly scanned are odd shaped, bound in some way, or for other reason require one-page-at-a-time scanning, and are therefore labor intensive. CascadeJoe is right that the cost can be avoided by inspecting the documents first and then asking for copies or scans of only the pages desired, or by making a more focused request.

Comment: We live in a 1600 sq foot townhome near the Canada Line. We can live in a big house (buy a west side Vancouver home with cash if I wanted to) but for the three of us, convenience trumps a big house. I grew up in a 7 bedroom house with only my parents, where my folks still live. Not worth it. I don't miss fighting traffic. I don't miss driving everywhere. I don't miss cleaning the massive house.
Right now, we have a park right in front of us where our kid can run around. There's a playground. We walk/bike everywhere. We have one car which saves on money. Going to work is hassle free on the skytrain, and cheap (yes it breaks down once in a blue moon but you're way more likely to be stuck in a traffic jam due to the idiot drivers here). Yes, we give up a bit of freedom and space but I know my neighbours and we look out for each other. Don't miss single family houses at all.

Comment: Whereas every other neurotransmitters enables nerve impulses to jump across the synaptic cleft, endocannabinoid compounds travel backward and interact with CB receptors strategically situated on “presynaptic nerve axons...retrograde signaling facilitates a process known as “presynaptic inhibition” which interrupts and slows down the release of other neurotransmitters such as norepinephrine and glutamate; and cannabinoid  receptors also transmit chemical signals that “slow down” the release of sedative neurotransmitters such as GABA (which binds to the same receptor as Valium and alcohol). By inhibiting GABA activity, the endocannabinoid system speeds things up (213). - Martin A. Lee, Smoke Signals

Comment: First of all, Canadian cities are not in a sub-tropical zone, so planning for those kind of rainfall levels is not warranted here.   I have never said that Canada doesn't need to up their game in planning and preventing the kinds of disasters that happen here.   Finally, I also have not said that you could entirely prevent the effects of that level of rainfall.  Obviously though, improved drainage will mitigate the effects to a significant extent..  If the Houston waters receded ten times as fast, that will mitigate the effects of ANY amount of rainfall, but obviously some level of damage may still occur.  Finally, one poster has pointed out that tides prevent effective drainage of the Houston area, and so, a seawall combined with pumps at high tide would then improve drainage significantly. Any seawall system in low or below sea level elevations has to be combined with ditches, canals and pumps to be effective. Don't arbitrarily rule out the usefulness of a seawall in this situation.

Comment: A good example of statistics that are designed to mask reality.  So what if Vancouver experiences a 30% decline in inquiries while, for three or four months, Calgary experiences a 300% increase.  If Vancouver started out with 15 times as many inquiries, it will still, at the point of maximum change, be the object of three and a half times as many inquiries as Calgary.  The article acknowledges, after a lot of hand waving, that things are returning to "normal" anyway, so the headline should have read "blip seen in foreign interest in Vancouver condo market occurs in summer 2016."   Half a million in Vancouver will buy you maybe a bachelor suite, or a tiny, old one-bedroom.  So  thousands of Chinese are are looking to house their kids for a few years while they attend school here, and to turn a profit in the process. That has practically nothing to do with the city's real problem, which is that investment money has been pouring in to a woefully inadequate supply of family housing.

Comment: Talking about my parents and the other sorts of abuse filled up our hour long sessions. When I recovered memories of the abuse, he was one of the first persons I called. Comment: This seems to be an article focused on the overarching discussiom of the regressive nature of Hawaii's GET rather than the surcharge vs. property tax issue. 

If you're truly being adversely impacted by the GET you can, to a degree, control that by reducing your consumption. But you have no control over your property taxes whatsoever.

*edit* I also just realized that this whole story is based on a wrong premise:  there hasn't been, to my knowledge, any discussion of RAISING the GET. The debate has been whether to extend the EXISTING surcharge or, in lieu of extending the surcharge, increase property taxes (or TAT) while retaining the GET surcharge through 2020-something.

Comment: I'm chuckling. You say we have freedom of speech with no qualifications. "Except..."

Yes, that's correct. We have freedom of speech with qualifications. However those limitations go far beyond simple incitement to violence. You may not slander or libel someone. You may not cause a public disturbance with your speech under some circumstances. You can't express yourself by way of child pornography. And you can't utter hate speech in public against an identifiable group. Those are some limitations off the top of my head; there may be others.

Theoretically, in law every Charter right can be limited and almost all of them are. As far as I know the only ones that aren't are "thought" rights, as in freedom of belief, conscience, etc. That's because while we can encourage people to think in certain ways, we can't (and shouldn't) make laws about what people think.

Comment: Actually the RCMP are doing what the law says.  They are arresting and detaining them under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and turning them over to Canada Immigration for processing.

There is a very good legal reason why refugee claimants (not asylum seekers which are a completely different class of persons) are not being charged in respect of their entry to Canada.

Under Article 31 of the 1951 Convention on Refugees Canada has undertaken to not prosecute refugee claimants for illegal entry into Canada including any issues of false documents or fraud relating to that entry.

Canada has enacted that exemption into our domestic law as required by the Convention in various iterations of our immigration legislation over the years. Currently that exemption is contained at s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

So no charges because the law exempts refugees recognizing that refugees who are fleeing persecution are different from other migrants.

Comment: AJ, I think we mostly agree, my point standing that any gap between the minimum size necessary and the actual size is where we find corruption. So to reduce corruption, an approach that doesn't depend on Icelandic luck is to systematically scale down on size. 

You seem to be saying "whatever size emerges by consensus is the right size", and I get your point, but it's circular. I'm arguing there's a right size independent of the actual size. 

Institute a hiring freeze in the Dept of Women and Children, and I'm pretty sure women and children will be okay. Employ 500 more in that department, and they'll do no better. Right size? Probably zero.

In the private sector, the right and actual sizes of companies are not independent, because any divergence produces opportunity cost that shareholders act to resolve. Yet in a democracy people don't in fact have the power to put "smaller government" on the agenda, only to accept it, if offered, and by proxy.

Comment: Trump's secretary of state has reported to Congress that Iran is complying with its obligations under its Nuclear Arms Treat. The treaty has given us insights into Iran's program and the location of its facilities and how the program was to work. If Iran violates the treaty and military action is required, we can effectively attack key targets. However, after Bush tore up our treaty with North Korea 15 years ago, North Korea has stepped up its program in deep secrecy and we cannot effectively target key facilities, particularly since North Korea has been mobilizing and hardening its facilities and weapons. US military strategists supported both treaties because of the inside view it gives us of their programs. In hindsight would have been good to keep the treaty and work to keep tightening it.

Comment: The guideline harvest levels (GHLs) are based on a percentage of the total biomass. Comment: Cooking the books is a recipe for disaster -- especially for the cooks.  The San Diego officials charged with fraud were accused of purposely underfunding the City's pension system.  The pension system of the City and County of Honolulu is wrapped up with the pension systems of the other counties and the State in one large pension system.  That pension system is underfunded by $12 billion.  It's a big number, but it's still a very optimistic estimate because it assumes that the $15 billion in assets of the pension system can be invested at a 7% return in investments.  Recently, however, the return was a negative 1%.  Assuming a more realistic 2% over the course of many years, the pension fund would be underfunded by $35 billion, and not $15 billion.  Of course, only a part of that would be the City's responsibility.  However, if the City is purposely underfunding its pension system, the responsible City officials might be worried about being charged with fraud.

Comment: Charles P. Wathen's solution to the affordable housing crisis is problematic because it requires undesirable additional taxes and the conversion of precious agricultural or conservation land to be used for housing.  There's a better solution.  All land that is currently zoned for single family homes from Kahala to Kalihi should be rezoned for low rise apartments, including Kaimuki, Kapahulu, Moiliili, Manoa, Nuuanu, and Liliha.  That would create an economic incentive to increase the supply of housing, which would have the effect of driving down housing prices.  These areas would eventually look more like McCully, where small apartment buildings are mixed in with single family homes.  This solution would increase the concentration of housing on existing urbanized lands instead of destroying precious agricultural or environmental resources, and it wouldn't require any additional taxes.

Comment: Unlike Ibbitson, I don't think the strong population growth in Canada is due to enlightened political leadership. Therefore, potentially controversial topics such as immigration are generally never addressed at all, or never discussed thoughtfully and realistically, in a balanced way, by any of the main political leaders. If the subject is discussed at all, we usually get a few brief slogans and platitudes, meant to gather votes in selected  jurisdictions. There is no long-term plan or foresight.  According to this simple way of thinking, having more and more people will lead to having more and more older adults who will need the support of more and more younger people and so the population should grow continuously and indefinitely. However, at some point this cycle has to stop, since  limitless and continuous population growth is clearly not possible forever in a world of finite resources.

Comment: I can't help but laugh at your posts.  I'm sorry, but you're biased as hell.

You know the early Ottomans split up the Empire into administrative units called Eyalets and these rarely - if ever - aligned with any kind of historical boundaries of the local tribes, or with any kinds of historically known borders, right?And you know that even the late Ottomans, who got a lot more organized and created the Vilayet system, with even finer district bounders and borders, still didn't align those Vilayets with any kind of historical boundaries.

In fact, if you lay a map of their administrative divisions over the League of Nation's Mandate system, you'll see the Europeans largely followed the Ottoman's Vilayet boundaries when they came up with the mandate borders.

So for 800 years, Ottoman Turks can carve up the region and it's not colonialism and has no effect on future events, at all.  The Europeans come along, and presto, magico!  Colonialism.

Comment: Anyone who has lived in the country understands the brutality of nature. Animals kill to survive and fight to the death. A cornered animal experiences a surge of sudden ferocity. During its final minutes, when the animal knows it’s going to die, it will emit a specific sound, a warning to others of the same species. That sound is known as a death cry. I believe we are hearing the death cry of the G.O.P. in its current incarnation: racist obstructionists who welcomed the squalid alt-right into their midst and failed to produce a credible nominee for president. They had their chance, and blew it. They dismantled unions, systematically attacked education, and ignored the separation of church and state. They gave corporations the same rights as people while trampling the rights of actual human beings. Unlike other animals, which know the death cry as a warning, too many Americans are responding with a sense of outraged empowerment. —Chris Offutt

Comment: "Over a seven-month period, the Commission analyzed the state’s criminal justice system, including a comprehensive review of sentencing, corrections, and community supervision data. Key findings include: 
• Alaska’s pretrial population has grown by 81 percent over the past decade, driven primarily by longer lengths of stay for both felony and misdemeanor defendants.
• Three-quarters of offenders entering prison post-conviction in 2014 were convicted of a nonviolent offense.
• Length of stay for sentenced felony offenders is up 31 percent over the past decade.
• In 2014, 47 percent of post-revocation supervision violators – who are incarcerated primarily for non-criminal violations of probation and parole conditions – stayed more than 30 days, and 28 percent stayed longer than 3 months behind bars...the state’s growing prison population and increased corrections spending have failed to produce commensurate improvements in public safety..."  ACJC Dec. 2015

Comment: Actually the courts have allowed for the use of National Guard as long as they are funded by the State and not the Federal Government thus avoiding the the issue of the federal government using federal military personnel to enforce domestic policies within the United States. Posse Comitatus only specifically applies to the United States Army and, as amended in 1956, the United States Air Force. While the Act does not explicitly mention the United States Navy and the United States Marine Corps, the Department of the Navy has prescribed regulations that are generally construed to give the Act force with respect to those services as well. The Act does not apply to the National Guard under state authority from acting in a law enforcement capacity within its home state or in an adjacent state if invited by that state's governor.

We've got a museum that now looks like a metal office box structure.  And we used to have tiny white Christmas lights all over the city.  We're there even any Christmas decorations downtown?  If there were, I missed seeing them.  And the only stuffed bear downtown seems to be a soggy, dirty oversized stuffed toy.  Why would tourists bother when it's so discouraging for a long time resident?

Comment: Actually, one could rather quickly reduce CO2 emissions and spur clean-energy adoption. It involves the same type of regulations that have been discussed in Kyoto and Paris, about capping carbon emissions, and committing to reductions. If we give time lines of 10-15 years, businesses will have time to adapt to the shifts by building different types of plant, moving from coal and natural gas to solar and wind farms.

The fact is that doing nothing, which is what we are doing, is going to set up an economic nightmare. As the earth warms, some of the world's best cultivation lands will become more difficult to farm. Clean water for drinking will be reduced, forcing increased reliance on energy dependent (and with dirty power, CO2 emitting) technology. Food scarcity could become a major factor.
From a national security perspective, it has a real potential to destabilize global allies, and threaten American military supremacy. That's the official Pentagon position, not opinion, its fact.

Comment: University of Washington neurologist Ethan Russo postulates that “clinical endocannabinoid deficiency” underlies migraines, fibromyalgia, IBD, and a cluster of other degenerative conditions which may respond favourably to cannabinoid therapies... CB receptor signaling modulates pain and analgesia, inflammation, appetite, gastrointestinal motility, neuroprotection and neurogeneration, along with the ebb and flow of immune cells, hormones, and other mood-altering neurotransmitters such as serotonin, dopamine, and glutamate (213). Cannabinoids (endo [naturally occurring], herbal, and synthetic) are anti-inflammatory; they literally cool the body. But... if the immune system overreacts to chronic stress or mistakes one’s body for a foreign object, then the stage is set for another autoimmune disease or an inflammatory disorder to develop.

MJ also eases peripheral neuropathy, which also affects cancer patients and diabetics (229-230). - Martin A. Lee, Smoke Signals

Comment: Disgusted with the Globe: You raise an interesting point. No cultural or religious group holds a monopoly on either hatred or virtue. I've posted comments over the past couple days, some of which have been deleted (although without any indication from the moderator(s) that they're uncivil), noting that there are two competing views of human rights, the first being the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the second the being the Cairo Declaration of Human Rights in Islam. The CDHRI, to which I believe over 40 Muslim-majority countries are signatories, is essentially an oppositional response to the UDHR. It sets out the 'legal' basis for Muslim exceptionalism and is seen as a mainstream approach in much of the Islamic world and presumably among many Muslims who are living in the West. Apparently, we're not supposed to point out such inconsistencies in insular little Canada. The divide between the West and Islam is real and it hasn't been entirely created by or in the West.

Comment: Some food for thought - a career civil servant with a defined benefit pension plan will be making on average anywhere between $50k and $90k as pension for the rest of their lives. They also will have RRSPs and other personal savings to draw upon for retirement as a supplement. An employee in the private sector upon retirement (even with a defined contribution plan) will have a good amount of cash to utilize in addition to his/her RRSPs and other personal savings for retirement. Our shopkeeper upon retiring with $750k (at the stupendous rate of 7%) in his/her corporation is not so well off now eh? Assuming he/she holds $750k in personal assets, they will be able to enjoy a pension comparable to a retired civil servant after taking far greater risks over their career. But of course, you feel that at $50k/yr they are still getting too good a deal. It is possible to accumulate $750k in a small business - but in almost all cases, it can only happen after a lifetime of hard work...

Comment: The best public art I have ever seen is in the little city of Windsor, Ontario.

You walk along the riverside park there and, over the course of about three miles, you pass by a few dozen big sculptures of all sorts, some frivolous and light with animals and abstraction, some heavy and monumental with themes of war and peace, some difficult to interpret but interesting nonetheless.

That is the best approach to public art. A mix and variety, not to heavy on any one theme, not too preachy and not having only one message seemingly approved by some heavy-handed government big brother type.

The public art that I can't stand is the type were a ton of taxpayer money goes in to one loud, single-themed, preachy, one-note noise of cloying proselytization, sitting there on its own like an ulcer (unless you are a true believer who has swallowed big brother's government-sanctioned cool-aid, you love it). And sadly, in recent decades, Vancouver has drifted more and more into that second group...

Comment: Did you read the article?  The whole point is that, as private citizens, we are not bound by the strictures a court is. This makes perfect sense. I can't throw you in jail - no matter what I think you may be guilty off. A judge CAN.
So a judge is held to a higher standard - one of the principles of that standard is that he is required to presume innocence if he is presiding over your trial.

But there's no such requirement for me (or Professor De Vos) as ordinary citizens. It would be a gross violation of my right to freedom of opinion and freedom of expression to say that I can't have my own opinion. Both before and after a trial - we have the right to think judges err - they are only human after all, this is why there is an appeals process: because even the judiciary itself recognizes that it's not an infallible institution.
I believed, at the time, that the judge in the Oscar Pistorius case had erred by sentencing him too lightly. As it happens: the appeals the appeals court agreed.

Comment: I support LED streetlights. However, as usual, Eugene's staff botched the implementation. Rather than doing a couple of small, inexpensive demonstrations and soliciting feedback, they just charged ahead and mess the whole thing up. The lights they chose are:

3. Wrong frequencies of light. The color chosen competes with bike lights and some motor vehicle lights, which makes those objects harder to see

I'm waiting for the $10M lawsuit when the first child cracks his skull open on them. Comment: I agree . However not all projects are good ones merely because they are oil develop or move oil. 
It is not anti- industry to look at each project carefully. And it is not acceptable to keep ignoring the external costs of pollution:
"Private costs to firms or individuals do not always equate with the total cost to society for a product, service, or activity. The difference between private costs and total costs to society of a product, service, or activity is called an external cost; pollution is an external cost of many products. External costs are directly associated with producing or delivering a good or service, but they are costs that are not paid directly by the producer. When external costs arise because environmental costs are not paid, market failures and economic inefficiencies at the local, state, national, and even international level may result."
http://www.frbsf.org/education/publications/doctor-econ/2002/november/private-social-costs-pollution-production/

Comment: If you can field bear spray you can field a gun (as a generalization, handicaps etc... aside). If you field bear spray it may work to redirect the bear, maybe... or you may, due to wind or weather spray yourself or your friends or the bear and he may or may not care, like the kayak lady at Berg Bay or the bears at Yellowstone etc...  It may not penetrate the heavy rains we are known for in Southeast. All of which may happen to a fully competent and prepared user. Compare that to a fully prepared competent user of a firearm and there isn't even a contest. Bullets don't care about wind or water and don't stray from where they are put (to any degree relevant here, though they may deflect after getting there).

The firearm doesn't automatically stop bear attacks from happening nor shoot the bear for you before it can do harm. No sane person argued such. If there is no time to deploy there is no time to deploy.

But if you want to pretend you're making a valid point don't let me stop you.

Comment: On the face of it, it seems crazy to give away over 20% of the company away at such a low price.  Has Baker's view of the Real Estate value changed negatively? That's very unlikely - in fact selling the NY L&T flagship well above the last valuation will only bolster his view.  So what's his game?  On one level it does have the effect of diluting Litt's holding - a cute way of putting the upstart in his place.  And it also answers criticisms about lack of independence on the board. But there has to be more than that.  He must see tremendous value in this new, clearly active relationship with WeWork, such that giving up a chunk of equity (and 2 board seats) is short-term pain for...well you can guess the rest.  The press release alludes to a series of transactions - which he hopes will unlock huge value over time.   Yes, it's a gamble, but Baker has done this before with Zellers.  When all becomes clear, it will be too late for new investors to jump aboard the HBC train.

Comment: I've been hiring individuals for years. Someone's degree is pointless - for the most part - my HR partners will ask if it's important and I'll simply say as long as they have 4 more years in the same field, I'll waive the degree requirement.

I hire people with 10+ years (if they have 25 or 35 even better) with real proven experience in their field. I get resumes with 'published this piece with this publication'. Means nothing to me. On the other hand, if they have multiple implementations of their work that achieved what I am looking for PLUS they're great communicators, then I'll hire them on the spot.

Critical thinking is key folks. The ability to memorize something and be able to recite it back during an exam is useless in the world. Being able to take a concept and turn it into a solution PLUS communicate how you're going to get there is the secret sauce every employer should be looking for.

How you obtained those skills, I do not care. The fact you have them is what I look for.

Comment: True... the number of farmers and the number of farms continue to decline.

But everyone has to eat, including inmates. The prison farms produced meat, vegetables and dairy products for the local inmate population (Kingston once had at least 7 federal institutions). 

Furthermore, the skills that an inmate (or anyone) can learn on a farm are extensive and highly applicable: machinery maintenance & repair, welding, fencing & building, animal husbandry & vet care, feeding & nutrition, milking & sanitation, planting & fertilizing & harvesting, greenhouse work, egg grading, etc.

Plus learning fundamental work habits like rolling out of bed & showing up on time, completing the task you are assigned, accepting responsibility for your mistakes, etc.

What's often overlooked is that many of these guys are doing time because they had a hard time getting along with people. Driving a tractor for hours gives a person plenty of time to think & reflect, free of intrusions and interpersonal hassles.

Comment: I'm sorry, but this column is appallingly incomplete.

First, many people who receive end-of-life care at home are not terminally ill, in the sense of active disease causing imminent death, or under hospice care. They are old and eventually die from the circulatory, respiratory, neuromuscular or other systemic failure that comes with old age.

Second, by law (HRS 327C-1), death may be declared by a physician, osteopath, or nurse. Any of those may be providing care preceding death, even if they are not affiliated with a hospice entity.

If family or other caregivers follow the advice given here, they risk inviting an unnecessary, aggressive, and sometimes violent medical intervention. It's not the fault of the EMT's, it's their job to respond as if it's an emergency and attempt to "save" the person's life, as Shayne Enright said.

The advice should have been to have a licensed professional visit the patient before death, and arrange to call them to pronounce death when the time comes.

Comment: Another factual error. Thomas didn't represent Spenard. Legislative records refer to him as being "from" Spenard, but that's likely because his mailing address was at the Spenard post office. This was the case with Helen Beirne, who actually lived in Glen Alps. Far as I know, Thomas lived on a tract on the west end of Raspberry Road, currently home to a subdvision bearing the street names Lowell and Tay. The state constitution originally apportioned the Senate based on area. Anchorage shared two senators with the rest of Southcentral and parts of Southwest plus a third senator with Mat-Su. Egan reapportioned the Senate following the Reynolds v. Sims decision ("one man, one vote"), which gave Anchorage 7 Senate seats, but that district encompassed all of Anchorage. The reapportionment for the 1972 election created multiple House districts in Anchorage but kept the one Senate district in place. This was a key issue in the Supreme Court's 1974 reapportionment plan, which held though 1980.

Comment: The word "science" means knowledge. The method for gathering knowledge of the natural world is through careful, documented observation, often of a controlled experiment based on a hypothesis and a simplified situation. The results are predictive knowledge that is generalizable, but often at a simplistic level that is blind to nature's most complex creations - healthy, stable ecosystrms.

Traditional knowledge is also based on careful observation,  but usually of complex, real-world ecological interactions where one lives.  It is also useful, but is more grounded in particular places (this valley, this forest, this prairie) and less generalizable. The depth of this ecological knowledge is impressive, and produces a sophisticated spiritual appreciation of our planet.

As humanity uses Western science to exploit, monetize and destroy the ecosystems on which we depend, there is a need to learn from the traditional wisdom of first peoples. Otherwise, our species will go extinct.

Comment: Instead, HSTA should try to restructure the DOE to improve student learning.  Currently, the DOE is too top-heavy, and the bureaucrats in the central office justify their existence by issuing directives to school administrators and teachers.  They have little experience with the conditions at the schools themselves, and as a result, many of these directives are ineffective.  The school faculty becomes overburdened by having to comply with directives that they know won't work.  That's why the morale of teachers and principals is at a historic low.

Comment: A chaplain is valuable in traumatic times of grief. Some people aren't much for prayers, but when someone they know has passed or is in pain it is often a time for prayers. The chaplain is completely separate, they ask if the person would like them to pray with them, and often they wait until loved ones arrive on scene. Cops & EMS focus on the victims/incident. So what exactly are you referencing when you say "Time to get rid of this much-abused program"? Don't dismiss the purpose of a chaplain. When my daughter is surrounded by EMS and being loaded into the back of an ambulance, and I am terrified as I watch her little body convulse and eyes rolled back in ER head, I'm saying please God just let her be alright, I will gratefully take all the prayers in the world. I've spent hours in ICU rooms and just knowing that someone is there to pray and offer emotional suffer is very calming. A chaplain is experienced with death notifications where a psychologist is used in a clinical setting.

Comment: This is the first DUI conviction that I see - his other alcohol-fueled shennagin didn't allege a vehicle. Even if he was convicted previously,and since DUI is a misdemeanor in Cali, his Colorado conviction couldn't be considered as we don't have a misdemeanor reciprocal sentencing-enhancement agreement with California. That being said, a conviction in California can be considered against his Colorado Probation as terms of probation in Colorado require that the probatee not be convicted of any local, state, or Federal offense in any jurisdiction anywhere in Colorado or in any other state. Since his conviction occurred in August of 2015, he would be within the 2 year window; However, Arapahoe County offers early probation termination if the probatee has complied with all terms and conditions of probation AND if all fees and fines are paid in full. The probatee can apply for this relief after 1/2 of the sentence is completed - so he may already be off-paper in Colorado.

Comment: Article I-Section 10, Clause 3 of the U.S. Constitution specifically permits states to enter interstate compacts. In fact, there are hundreds of major compacts currently in force (and thousands of minor ones).

The U.S. Supreme Court has ruled that congressional consent is only necessary for interstate compacts that ‘encroach upon or interfere with the just supremacy of the United States [U.S. Steel Corporation v. Multistate Tax Commission, 1978].’ Because the choice of method of appointing presidential Electors is an “exclusive” and “plenary” state power, there is no encroachment on federal authority.
Thus, under established compact jurisprudence, congressional consent would not be necessary for the National Popular Vote compact to become effective.

Comment: Hello folks, a cool quote from a textbook:

"The development of cooperative hunting of large mammals by our ancestors led to the formation of cohesive all male hunting groups" (from Social Behavior in Animals).

Anyways before that, way, way, way back, those earlier mammals were likely hunters, namely insectivores, and, because of their very tiny size, it is likely that the females had to be wrapped among her young to keep them warm, both by providing milk and sharing her body heat by direct contact. The smaller your young, the more rapidly they cool, the more often they need feeding. In the existent small insectivores still alive to this day, the males have much larger territories than females, again getting back to greater demands on spatial perception and geometry. And the act of males bringing adult females food to aid in steps of embryo/fetal/young development? That predates considerably the last common ancestor of mammals, being present in birds and, it is thought, dinosaurs!

Comment: Terrorism- at least the kind one can hope to prevent- is only a minute fraction of the threats that exist to Canadian society. As we've seen repeatedly in Britain and elsewhere, life goes on regardless even when a terrorist attack is successful. Few in the public are affected and the impact- though dramatic- is localized. Not so with organized crime. It's impact is spread across all of society. Far greater numbers of people are negatively impacted by organized crime than a terrorist could ever hope to achieve. The difference is that organized crime conducts its far more harmful business in the shadows, while terrorists act in highly visible ways. Politicians play the visible threat for all its worth while throwing resources at countering it. The tougher nut, even though its far more pernicious, gets ignored.

Comment: I couldn't agree more.  Back in the 80s and 90s, I used to buy almost all major appliances from Sears.  I had nothing but Kenmore dishwashers, stoves, refrigerators, washers/dryers, etc. -- both in my own home, and in my parents' home.  But as those appliances got older and needed repairs, I found the customer service from Sears to be HORRIBLE.  Poor product quality.  Incompetent repair technicians.  Ridiculously long wait times.  Convoluted call routing systems.  Etc. etc.  It isn't often that I've needed to get in a supervisor's face and literally yell and swear at him/her; but with Sears (at least back in the 2000s when I still dealt with them) that's what I was reduced to doing.

It's been well over 10 years now since I've had anything to do with Sears.  All those Kenmore appliances are long gone.  And it'll be a cold day in hell before I ever set foot in a Sears store again for anything!

Comment: While AC is small in the global scheme, it's impact on micro-climates can indeed be quite huge. I remember one fine day in the Central Valley that was a bit on the warm side, as summer days tend to be down there. Several of us were having an early dinner outside and the host happened to look at her thermometer. I believe it was around 103F. 

Just then, we had a power outage. It became wonderfully quiet as all the nearby air conditioners went silent. About half an hour later, we noticed the temperature was much cooler (even though we were still at what should have been the heat of the day). Our host again looked at the thermometer and it was about a dozen degrees cooler, all simply because the AC's were no longer heating up the neighborhood. The mature trees no doubt had some effect as well, but the key was turning off those air conditioners.

How do we do it? Well, improved building codes would be a start, and better architecture and tougher people are needed as well.

Comment: I can't say I agree with the hedged/unhedged comments in the article.
For my US S&P portion I've used both Vanguard Canada's VFV (unhedged) and VSP (hedged).
When I started in 2013 the CDN $ was quite close to par - well above historical long term averages - so I chose VFV.  Early last year when the CDN $ dropped below 70 cents US 
I figured it was time to swap so I am now in VSP.  I'll stay there until we hit 80 cents and then maybe swap half back.  Unless oil rebounds significantly (doubtful) I can't see the CDN $going above 85 cents US anytime soon.
It is interesting to see what has happened on a comparison chart for VFV and VSP over the past 30 days versus the past 3 years.

Comment: Contrary to the notion that the country’s health care is primarily a privately funded system, 71 percent of health care expenditures in California are paid for with public funds, according to a new analysis by the UCLA Center for Health Policy Research….

“The public sector is the primary player in health care spending,” said Gerald Kominski, director of the UCLA Center for Health Policy Research who led the study. “But monies are disbursed in a fragmented way through numerous different entities, each of which has their own system and way of doing things. The question for policy makers is, ‘does this fragmented approach make sense?’”

“For a majority of Californians, a public-run system is already the reality ... a single-payer system could unite all these various programs and expand them to the entire population, resulting in a more streamlined and cost-effective approach to health care spending.”

Comment: I'm not sure if I'm misunderstanding or if Amy is misunderstanding the ticket issue.  It sounded to me like the host couple received their 2 tickets for free, but invited the other couple to go along who had to purchase their own 2 tickets at face value.  It sounded like the invitees were complaining at paying the whole price of the tickets rather than the host couple paying for half of the additional (non-free) tickets.   In that case, I don't think it is the business of the invited couple to know how much the host paid for their own tickets.  If they went out to dinner with another person and that person received a senior citizen discount on their food (for example) would they demand that the person pick up part of their tab to balance out?  Each person obtains a ticket and pays whatever the cost was for their own ticket which is what happened here.  The hosts *could* have offered to split the fee but were not obligated.

4.  HFA does not exist in water at the tap.  It is not ingested. Comment: Hawaii Census of 1890 (Kingdom):  Total population 89,990;  Hawaiian  34,436;  Part Hawaiian 6,186.  Therefore ethnic Hawaiians (full or part) total 40,622 out of 89,990 which is 45%.
Hawaii Census of 1896 (Republic):  Total population 109,020;  Hawaiian 31,019;  Part Hawaiian 8,485. Therefore ethnic Hawaiians (full or part) total 39,504 out of 109,020 which is 36%.  
U.S. Census of 1900 (Territory):  Total population 154,001;  Hawaiian 29,799;  Part Hawaiian 9,857.  Therefore ethnic Hawaiians (full or part) total 39,656 out of 154,001 which is 26%.
U.S. Census of 2000: Ethnic Hawaiians 401,000.

The facts show that at the time the monarchy was overthrown in 1893, and continuing until the beginning of the Territorial period in 1900, there were slightly fewer than 40,000 ethnic Hawaiians.  But by 2000 there were more than 400,000. Thus THE POPULATION OF ETHNIC HAWAIIANS MULTIPLIED TENFOLD DURING THE FIRST CENTURY OF U.S. SOVEREIGNTY IN HAWAII.  2010: 527,000.  Now: 600,000.  Thriving!

(ii)Money in politics. Francis has spoken out against the "idolatry of money". Clinton has contributed to a culture of the corporatization of our political process

(iii)Climate Change. Francis has spoken of a "social and cultural revolution" to deal with Climate Change. Clinton and Obama quite frankly have not measured up to the demand of a revolution to deal with Climate Change and in the case of Clinton supports harmful policies like fracking. 

She's got a long way to go to earn the trust of a lot of people.

Comment: Quite honestly, the monitoring system results in comments that end up matching the "majority" opinion. Irrespective of whether that is generated by reason or emotion. A highly partisan thread will close in and reinforce itself - whether it is reasonable or rational, or not. The comments ultimately become self reinforcing and don't give a fair representation of the full range of opinions that are expressed.

This "self monitoring" system can also easily be manipulated to presented a slanted view - depending on how the participants answer the questions when they comment. It cannot help but be slanted, unless, perhaps, participants answer the questions honestly and without partisan bias. Based on what I've seen,  and knowing some of the regular hyper partisan posters here, that is not going to happen.

Comment: Noobles, yes,  SOME rights that are clearly universal, should not have to be "earned" anew by each generation. Among these, freedom of speech, religion, freedom to associate in groups of like-minded people.

But at some point you hit an issue, illustrated by Gilligan's Island, the TV show where about a dozen people get stuck on an island together for years after their boat crashes there.

Should they on Gilligan's Island have the above rights? Sure, they do not cost money, nor need technology. If Maryanne wants to worship trees as a druid, if Gilligan wants to tell others that he hopes US President Johnson improves streets back home, terrific, have at it.

But what if Ginger wants a safe abortion? And what if the Professor gets a rare blood disease that costs a million dollars a year to treat? And what if Maryanne gives birth to a malformed infant costing 2 million a year to keep alive?

Out of luck, 3 of 3, on island. Probably out of luck, 2 of 3, in Canada.

Limits exist.
